page.title: 19Local History
page.content: Under the entry "LINDEAN" a modern gazetteer of Scotland merely adds: "Ancient parish embraced by Galashiels parish". Long before the parochial system was introduced or the place name bestowed,hunters and fishers had fashioned their flints on a bluff overlooking the River Tweed near its confluence with Ettrick Water.In or about the first century B.C.native tribesmen built forts on the summits of local hills,e.g.,The Rink and Cauldshiels.Early in the 12th century,Prince David made a gift of land near the burgh of Selkirk -Selkirk Abbatis- to missionary monks in the hope that they would use it as the site of an abbey.They preferred a more suitable site at Kelso and part of -Selkirk Abbatis- was used as the site of a parish church,originally of Lindean and later of Galashiels.
